details.title: Comparison of Expected Failure Times for Several Replacement Policies

p: Félix Belzunce obtained a PhD (1996) in Mathematics from Murcia University. He is a Professor of Statistics at Universidad de Murcia (SPAIN). His main research interests are nonparametric classification, ordering and dependence of distributions with applications in reliability, survival, economics and stochastic processes, and reliability and survival nonparametric inference. He has published several papers on nonparametric classification, ordering, dependence, and nonparametric inference.

Eva-María Ortega graduated obtaining the award of degree with special distinction in Mathematics (1996), and obtained a PhD (2001) in Mathematics, both from University of Murcia. Her main research interests are stochastic orderings, nonparametric classification and dependence of distributions, with applications in actuarial science, reliability and survival, and she has published several papers on these topics. She teaches Statistics, and Operations Research at University Miguel Hernández; and she is a researcher at the Operations Research Center.

José M. Ruiz obtained a PhD (1979) in Mathematics at Universidad de Murcia, and was appointed a full Professor (1988) there. His research interests are in characterization of distributions, classification and ordering of distributions with applications in reliability, survival and economics, and reliability and survival nonparametric inference. He has supervised 9 PhD theses, and has published several papers on characterization, classification and ordering, and reliability and survival nonparametric inference.

details.abstract: Planned replacement policies are used to reduce the incidence of system failures, or to return a failed system to work. New better than used aging classes are commonly used in reliability theory to model situations in which the lifetime of a new unit is "better" than the lifetime of a used one. The purpose of this paper is to establish comparisons of expected failure times of an age (block) replacement policy, and a renewal process with no planned replacements when the lifetime of the unit is NBUE. As we will see, age and block replacement policies improve the stochastic behavior compared with the renewal process with no planned replacements when the underlying distribution is NBUE. Some interpretations, applications, and a discussion about some related results are included

references.title: Statistical Theory of Reliability and Life Testing: Probability Models

context.text: The two planned replacement policies most commonly used are age, and block replacement policies (see [1]).

Several authors give results which involve stochastic comparisons of age, and block replacement policies; to renewal processes with no planned replacements in terms of the aging property of the interarrival times distribution (for example, Barlow & Proschan [1], Shaked & Zhu [9], Yue & Cao [10], and Belzunce & Ortega & Ruiz [11]).
Now, we recall the definition of the \$NBUE\$ aging class (see [1]).
Many papers deal with the properties of the \$NBUE\$ aging class: some closure properties under reliability operations are studied in [1], [12]–[16]; and reliability bounds are stated in [17].
Several properties in the context of renewal processes concerning the \$NBUE\$ aging class are developed in [1], [9], [18], and [19].
